stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware Implant Uses Public Storage Mechanisms for Exfiltration
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On or around 25 April 2015, a U.S. Government Agency released information regarding malware that uses persistent public storage mechanisms in conjunction with command and control(C2) infrastructure. The public storage mechanisms are used for exfiltration, as well as malware delivery. These storage services include Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox. The malicious actor utilized The Onion Router (TOR) to obfuscate remote access and potentially exfiltrate data. To obfuscate C2 traffic, the malicious actor uses a plugin called Meek that is installed as a service called google Update within TOR. Meek utilizes transport layer security (TLS) to encrypt communications and relay traffic through a legitimate third party, such as the services listed above.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious file was named WERMGR.EXE (file size: 50688). Within the file properties of malware, identified by the source as IMPLANT 4, the version information is identical to the benign system file also called WERMGR.EXE. This system file is found on 64-bit systems in the system32 directory. Using this technique is required to legitimize the malware. The implant is HTTP based and written in .NET. It's core capabilities include the ability to remotely execute PowerShell commands and download then execute local files on the target system. When files are remotely downloaded to the target system, they are stored in the following directories:
<APPDATA>\Adobe <LOCALAPPDATA>\Temp IMPLANT 4 sleeps for five to ten minutes before calling back to the C2 site and then spawns an instance of Internet Explorer to send and receive traffic from the C2 server. This data is stored in the internet cache directory: <INTERNETCACHE>\Low\Content.IE5
The implant is also capable of using AES decryption, which it requires for processing the C2. There are two known variants of this particular malware. Both variants use a unique obfuscator and store the AES key differently. The second variant utilizes Twitter for C2.
The URL http://pivotglobalresources.com/bestpractices.html is one possible callback from WERMGR.EXE with an IP address resolution of 199.168.29.240.
The response content SHA256: 4cc51782f39393ae98b3e69bb6c24d5f2499cb606317da1023792823dc7511a0.
